PHILOSOPHY: Build large aerobic base, then sharpen with intensity
ZONES: 5–7 zones; predominance Z1–2, decreasing Z3–5 (pyramidal TD)
MICRO (WEEK): 1–2 high-quality workouts, many long Z2 sessions
TESTING: FTP / LT tests phase-end; endurance tests
EVIDENCE: Tønnessen 2014; Casado 2022 (systematic review on pyramidal elites)
WEAKNESSES: Time-hungry; slower gains in fitness for low-hour athletes
NOT FOR: <8 h/wk or many short high-intensity events
ROLE OF STRENGTH: Strength heavy in base (max/general), maintenance during build/peak

PHILOSOPHY: Most training easy, small amount very hard, minimal middle zone
ZONES: 3-zone model (below LT1, between LT1–LT2, above LT2); ~80% low, ~20% high
MACRO (YEAR): Often year-round 80/20 or slight variation; competition phase may shift
MESO (BLOCK): Blocks maintain ~80/20 ratio; meso might include 2 hard sessions/week
MICRO (WEEK): ~2 hard sessions + many easy sessions; strict hard/easy separation
TESTING: LT1 & LT2 testing or VO₂/threshold; periodic MAP
FEEDBACK LOOPS: HRV, RHR, interval performance, check easy days remain easy (Z1 purity)
EVIDENCE: Støggl & Sperlich 2014 (polarized vs others in well-trained athletes)
STRENGTHS: Big gains in tolerance, recovery-friendly, elite proven distribution
WEAKNESSES: Low specificity at threshold; discipline required to keep easy truly easy
NOT FOR: <5 h/wk (too little volume) or pure sprint/TT specialists
PROGRESSION STYLE: Increment intensity/hard work while keeping volume/ratio stable
LOAD METRIC OF TRUTH: Percentage of time in Zone1 + power/HR in interval workouts
ROLE OF STRENGTH: Strength integrated year-round; heavy + explosive emphasized

PHILOSOPHY: Emphasise sub-threshold intervals to maximise FTP / threshold power
MACRO (YEAR): Compressed base (higher intensity early) → Build → Peak
MESO (BLOCK): Blocks focus on increasing SST/TH time (2–3 sessions/week)
MICRO (WEEK): Weekly: 2–3 SST/TH sessions + filler easy rides
TESTING: FTP test every ~4–6 weeks (or LT test)
FEEDBACK LOOPS: ATL/CTL, monotony index, power at threshold or RPE change
EVIDENCE: Yetton 2021 coaching literature; common applied practice data
WEAKNESSES: Risk of monotony, less low-intensity volume, burnout possibility
NOT FOR: Ultra-endurance or athletes needing large volume base
PROGRESSION STYLE: Increase density: more minutes at SST/TH, more sessions per week
ROLE OF STRENGTH: Strength optional but beneficial; short efficient max strength sessions

PHILOSOPHY: Frequent maximal intervals, minimal volume – leverage stimulus of high intensity
ZONES: Dominant Z5–Z7 (VO₂max, anaerobic capacity) with very low Z1–2 volume
MACRO (YEAR): Often short macro; many use HIIT blocks rather than full-year model
MESO (BLOCK): Meso often short (2–4 weeks intense) followed by recovery or maintenance phases
MICRO (WEEK): Weekly: 3–4 interval sessions, very limited long easy sessions
FEEDBACK LOOPS: HRV, power changes in intervals, time-to-exhaustion
EVIDENCE: Hickson 1981 classic HIIT; summarized in modern reviews
STRENGTHS: Fast gains, power-focused, efficient for low volume
WEAKNESSES: Burnout risk, poor endurance/durability for long durations
BEST FOR: <6 h/wk with focus on short events
NOT FOR: Long steady endurance events (Ironman/ultra) or novices
PROGRESSION STYLE: Increase intensity / more intervals rather than more volume
ROLE OF STRENGTH: Strength crucial (max + power) to compensate volume shortfall

PHILOSOPHY: Target one capacity intensely per block, then shift focus
ZONES: Zone emphasis dependent on block (e.g. VO₂max, threshold, volume)
MACRO (YEAR): Macro = sequence of blocks (accumulation, transmutation, realization)
MESO (BLOCK): Mesocycles = short blocks (often 2–6 weeks) of focused overload → consolidation
MICRO (WEEK): Weekly in block: heavy load for focus zone (3–4 sessions) + maintenance elsewhere
TESTING: Tests at end of each block (VO₂max, threshold, sprint power)
FEEDBACK LOOPS: Block response: KPI improvement, fatigue/recovery monitoring
EVIDENCE: Rønnestad et al. 2014 block vs traditional cyclists (superior improvement)
STRENGTHS: Rapid limiter fixes, high specificity, tailored overload
WEAKNESSES: Risk of mis-timing, complexity, muscle-capacity trade-offs
NOT FOR: Beginners, monitoring-averse, many small races annually
ROLE OF STRENGTH: Strength as separate block: heavy/explosive in off-season; maintenance otherwise

PHILOSOPHY: Emphasise intensity early, then shift to volume/endurance later
ZONES: Early focus on Z4–Z5/VO₂ zones, then later more Z2 volume
MACRO (YEAR): Winter/early season high intensity → Spring/summer higher volume endurance → taper
MESO (BLOCK): Initial HIT block, then endurance block, then specificity
MICRO (WEEK): Early weeks high intensity; later weeks more long Z2 rides
TESTING: FTP/MAP test early; decoupling/endurance tests later
FEEDBACK LOOPS: Monitor early stress, later endurance metrics like decoupling
STRENGTHS: Winter-friendly for athletes with limited volume early
WEAKNESSES: Risk of endurance deficit if volume too late; less evidence across all sports
BEST FOR: Athletes constrained in winter or short lead-in
NOT FOR: Ultra/long steady events needing big base early
ROLE OF STRENGTH: Strength emphasised early season (max strength) then maintenance

PHILOSOPHY: Use daily readiness (HRV/RHR/RPE) to adjust intensity/volume
ZONES: Zones flexible; any zone may appear depending on readiness
MACRO (YEAR): Macro/focus durations flexible (phase lengths adapt to athlete)
MESO (BLOCK): Meso blocks flexible length; micro adjusts based on readiness
MICRO (WEEK): Weekly: hard/easy days assigned by readiness rather than fixed
TESTING: Tests on “green days”, interval performance trends
FEEDBACK LOOPS: HRV, RHR, mood, readiness → adjust load; CTL ramp monitored
EVIDENCE: Kiviniemi 2010 HRV research in endurance athletes (small n)
WEAKNESSES: Risk of undertraining if conservative; requires daily monitoring
NOT FOR: Rigid, time-driven plans; novices needing structure
PROGRESSION STYLE: Progression guided by readiness: more load when green, less when red
ROLE OF STRENGTH: Strength also autoregulated: heavy when green, mobility/recovery when red

PHILOSOPHY: Build aerobic engine by staying under LT1 (or MAF HR cap)
ZONES: Single zone (LT1 cap) for most sessions; minimal higher zones until base built
MACRO (YEAR): Long base (8–16+ weeks) of LT1 rides; later progression into other zones
MESO (BLOCK): Duration increases while HR cap maintained; often 4–6 week blocks
MICRO (WEEK): Many long rides at HR cap + occasional strides; few quality sessions
TESTING: MAF test (e.g. 30-min HR test) every 3–4 weeks for drift
EVIDENCE: Maffetone case data; field studies on fat oxidation and efficiency
STRENGTHS: Improves fat-oxidation, durability, low injury risk
WEAKNESSES: Slow high-end improvement; may lack high intensity adaptations
NOT FOR: Athletes needing quick gains in high-end power
LOAD METRIC OF TRUTH: Decoupling (HR drift) + pace at HR cap
ROLE OF STRENGTH: Strength foundational: general + mobility + durability, low neural demand

PHILOSOPHY: Structure training around CP and anaerobic work capacity (W′)
ZONES: Zones built around CP/W′ model: work above CP uses W′, ≤CP targets endurance
MACRO (YEAR): Macro shaped around CP/W′ trends (raise CP and maintain W′)
MESO (BLOCK): >CP sessions progressively increased; block lengths moderate
MICRO (WEEK): Weekly: mix 1–3 sessions above CP, supporting endurance below CP
FEEDBACK LOOPS: Monitor W′ balance (deplete/recharge rate) + CP trend
STRENGTHS: High precision, great for surge repeatability events
WEAKNESSES: Complex to monitor; can neglect durability & long steady endurance
BEST FOR: Events with repeated surges (crit, CX, some road)
NOT FOR: Pure ultra steady endurance with minimal surges
PROGRESSION STYLE: >CP work ↑; W′ recharge capacity ↑ before raising CP
LOAD METRIC OF TRUTH: W′ balance + CP trend + session >CP workload
ROLE OF STRENGTH: Strength focus on anaerobic power: heavy + explosive; sprint-oriented

PHILOSOPHY: Sculpt VO₂max/VLamax profile to match event demands
ZONES: Zones derived from VO₂max, VT1/VT2, VLamax metrics rather than FTP only
MACRO (YEAR): Macro phases target shifts in VO₂max and/or reduction in VLamax to “fit” event
MESO (BLOCK): Blocks: one for VO₂max ↑, another for VLamax ↓; then specificity
MICRO (WEEK): Targeted metabolic sessions + supporting endurance sessions
TESTING: Metabolic profiling tests (VO₂max, VLamax, fatmax) pre/post blocks
FEEDBACK LOOPS: Monitor VO₂max, VLamax, metabolic cost, fuel usage
STRENGTHS: High specificity to event metabolic demands
BEST FOR: Athletes needing fine metabolic tuning (triathlon, elite road)
NOT FOR: Simple recreational riders without lab access
PROGRESSION STYLE: Progress by marker: VO₂max ↑ or VLamax ↓, then event integration
LOAD METRIC OF TRUTH: VO₂max, VLamax, glycolytic rate, fatmax metrics
ROLE OF STRENGTH: Strength tailored: low VLamax → heavy strength; high VLamax → explosive work

PHILOSOPHY: Two threshold sessions per day aimed at raising LT1/LT2 power while controlling lactate
ZONES: Lactate-capped Z4 (around threshold) dominates; some Z2/Z3 for volume
MACRO (YEAR): High-volume threshold blocks, then taper to peak
MESO (BLOCK): Daily doubles of threshold sessions followed by easy volume weeks
MICRO (WEEK): Weekly: 2 threshold sessions/day + easy endurance rides
TESTING: Frequent lactate tests (cap session lactate below set mmol/L)
EVIDENCE: Norwegian elite endurance literature; Sandbakk et al. best-practice summaries
STRENGTHS: High repeatability, controlled load improvements in threshold power
WEAKNESSES: Very high recovery demand, risk of overuse/injury
BEST FOR: Elite athletes with full support team
NOT FOR: Athletes without strong recovery resources or dense race calendars
ROLE OF STRENGTH: Strength mostly minimal: core/mobility focus; heavy lifting limited

PHILOSOPHY: Very large volume of low intensity (Z1–Z2) to build durability and fat-oxidation capacity
ZONES: Mostly Z1–Z2; minimal higher intensities until later phases
MACRO (YEAR): Very long base (many weeks/months) → small intensity phase → race
MESO (BLOCK): Volume accumulation blocks (long rides) followed by short intensity or taper blocks
MICRO (WEEK): Many long Z2 rides (3–5+ hours) + few or no quality intervals
FEEDBACK LOOPS: Monitor HRV, mood, power/pace decoupling, long-ride endurance
EVIDENCE: Historical elite norms; Lydiard-style and pro endurance practice
STRENGTHS: Builds extreme durability, fuel efficiency, resilience
WEAKNESSES: Inefficient for low-hour athletes; slow improvements in high-end power
NOT FOR: Time-crunched athletes (<8 h/wk) or short/intense events
PROGRESSION STYLE: Volume ↑ over weeks → then introduce minimal intensity
ROLE OF STRENGTH: Strength year-round for durability: max strength + mobility

PHILOSOPHY: Integrates pyramidal base, polarized weeks, limiter-blocks, SST when needed, autoregulation & signal-triggered testing
ZONES: Zones adapt: base (pyramidal), quality weeks (polarized) + block-specific zones
MACRO (YEAR): Pyramidal year with inserted limiter blocks and polarized micro-cycles
MESO (BLOCK): Targeted blocks (VO₂, TH, durability) inserted into macro; weekly rotation of intensity via polarity
MICRO (WEEK): 2 hard + 3–4 easy; SST if time-crunched; readiness signals drive some sessions
TESTING: Testing triggered by signals/blocks (FTP, CP, LT1, VO₂ depending on block)
FEEDBACK LOOPS: HRV/RPE + CTL/TSB + KPI-based swap between blocks
EVIDENCE: Composite evidence across methods; aligns with multi-pillar endurance best practice
STRENGTHS: Highly flexible, durable AND targeted, suitable for most athletes
WEAKNESSES: Requires coaching judgment, monitoring and discipline; complexity may overwhelm
BEST FOR: Most athletes who can monitor & adjust but aren’t ultra-specialized
NOT FOR: Athletes refusing monitoring/feedback or wanting purely intuitive plan
LOAD METRIC OF TRUTH: Multi-signal load: CTL + HRV + HR drift + power durability + block KPIs
ROLE OF STRENGTH: Strength integrated year-round: max (base), explosive (VO₂ phases), stability (TH/SST), durability (volume blocks)
